awd_titl_txt: SCC-IRG Track 2: Community on Multimodality: Participatory Action, Service, and Support (COMPASS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Those in need of help often do not know how to locate or access service providers. Likewise, service-providing agencies often work in silos. The lack of communication also applies to volunteers; people do not know who to help and how they can be resourceful. Response becomes even more problematic when a problem demands the coordination of service providers, volunteers, and government structures, and after business hours, when the communication channels that can aid people in need become sparse. This project will (i) simplify the discovery and use of services, (ii) enable two-way communication between stakeholders (e.g., residents and service providers), (iii) deploy resources more efficiently, and (iv) assist stakeholders in assessing and promoting the wellbeing of their communities. The end result will be directly applicable to communities across the US, and has the potential to be influential beyond the human and physical services domain. It will advance computer science, electrical and computer engineering, and social and behavioral sciences to collectively address the challenges associated with this problem, and will create educational opportunities to encourage students to cross disciplinary boundaries. Women and underrepresented groups will be encouraged to participate in this project by collaborating with community-based organizations, and via programs at the University at Albany.

This multidisciplinary project takes a community-wide approach that will integrate people and data with analytics and engineering using social and behavioral sciences to maximize the efficiency of delivering human and physical services, and also improve the sense of connectedness of residents with service providers and government structures. The project will study the limitations of extant services, which will in turn inform the development of novel decision-making mechanisms with sufficient behavioral realism. The outcome will be an integrated "one-stop" service of services. This project will (i) develop new data mining methods for uncovering complex interdependencies within a dynamic sociotechnical system, (ii) devise novel information processing, machine learning, and control methods to dynamically optimize delivery of human and physical services under uncertainty with humans in the decision-making loop, and (iii) shed light on the ability of communities to integrate emerging technologies to become more connected in human interactions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
There is a disconnect between those in need and those willing to help. Often, the needs of individuals are fulfilled through human service organizations, collective action initiatives, and philanthropic individuals. However, the process of seeking services is slow and fragmented: (i) service providers often work in silos, (ii) people who seek help carry the burden of navigating through available services and eligibility criteria, and (iii) people who need services are often marginalized and vulnerable, some of whom may experience challenges with technology. Even more problematic is seeking help after business hours, when people become clueless about whom to reach. The goal of this project was to reduce the barriers of navigating available human services in the community, so that service providers can respond to issues more efficiently and collaboratively, thus improving the quality of life of community members. To achieve this goal, the project set forth to: (i) simplify the discovery and use of services, (ii) enable two-way communication between stakeholders (e.g., service seekers and service providers), (iii) deploy resources more efficiently, and (iv) assist stakeholders in assessing and promoting the wellbeing of their communities. Long-lasting partnerships with 9 organizations in the Capital district of New York were formed and community engagement activities (i.e., interviews, surveys, focus groups, shadowing) were carried out. Community dynamics including but not limited to interactions within the human services provision system, and technology use and barriers, were assessed. The insights gained from these activities informed the research agenda and the project outcomes. Dynamic instance-wise joint feature acquisition and prediction computational approaches for single and multi-view settings in simple and structured environments with multiple classifiers have been developed. Machine learning models for hierarchical multiclass classification have been devised. A framework for robust machine learning trained with noisy labels has been developed. An automated recommendation system to assign homeless individuals to vital housing resources has been designed, developed, tested and evaluated. The project trained and involved 4 undergraduate students (1 female), 18 MS students (10 females), 15 PhD students (11 females), and 1 postdoctoral fellow in research activities related to data analytics, network science, machine learning, social science and urban planning. Three doctoral students (1 in Computer Science, 2 in Electrical & Computer Engineering), two of them female, have successfully defended their dissertations. An integrated dataset of neighborhood-level socioeconomic, pedestrian friendliness, and service request data has been made publicly findable and accessible. A prototype Web crawler software to collect information semi-automatically about service providers has been developed. A proof-of-concept mobile application to democratize human services data and streamline the service seeking process has been designed and developed, as informed by discussions with human service organizations in Albany, NY. The proof-of-concept mobile app and its corresponding back end have been transitioned from the lab to practice. Prototype cyberinfrastructure to enhance the transparency, accountability, and oversight transparency of homeless serving organizations has been proposed. A tutorial on advances in feature selection/acquisition to enable resource-efficient machine learning was organized and presented at the 2024 SIAM International Conference on Data Mining. Conference papers and journal articles have been published. Other lines of research to be pursued by the investigators in the future have been identified.


Last Modified: 08/29/2024
Modified by: Daphney-Stavrou Zois
